childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1983-1995

Cabbage Patch Kids caused actual riots the year you were born. Parents threw punches in toy aisles. Stores needed security guards. A doll with a birth certificate and a yarn-hair head became the most coveted object in America, and the frenzy over it was your generation's introduction to consumer madness—even if you were too young to remember it.

The smell of a freshly opened pack of Garbage Pail Kids cards. The texture of Silly Putty pulling comics off the newspaper. The satisfying click of a View-Master advancing to the next slide. Your childhood had a physicality that kids raised on touchscreens will never understand.

At three, you watched the Challenger explode on live television—or more likely, watched the adults around you react in horror while Christa McAuliffe and six astronauts died seventy-three seconds after launch. Schools had tuned in because a teacher was going to space. Instead, an entire generation learned that the world could break without warning.

Saturday mornings were sacred. You woke up before your parents, poured your own bowl of sugary cereal—Cap'n Crunch, Lucky Charms, Cookie Crisp—and planted yourself in front of the TV. He-Man and the Masters of the Universe. Transformers. G.I. Joe. Thundercats. These weren't just cartoons; they were twenty-two-minute toy commercials, and you didn't care because the toys were incredible.

Your Nintendo was the center of your social universe. You blew into cartridges like it was science. You knew the Konami code by heart. You debated whether Mario or Zelda was better with the intensity of a theological dispute. When your parents told you to go outside and play, you brought your Game Boy.

Friday nights meant one thing: Blockbuster. Walking those aisles with their distinct carpet-cleaner-and-plastic smell, running your fingers across VHS spines, negotiating with siblings. The crushing disappointment when someone else had already rented your movie. The backup choice that sometimes turned out better. You probably rented The Princess Bride or The Goonies so many times your parents should have just bought them.

You ate Lunchables and felt sophisticated. You drank Ecto Cooler—the green Hi-C with Slimer on the box—until they discontinued it and broke your heart. You collected Pogs without fully understanding the game. You had a Trapper Keeper with the velcro that never stayed stuck and a Lisa Frank folder with dolphins jumping over rainbows. These were status symbols.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

You're an elder Millennial—born in the third year of a generation that spans 1981 to 1996. The term 'Millennial' wouldn't become a pejorative until you were well into your twenties, when suddenly it became shorthand for entitled, narcissistic, and inexplicably obsessed with avocados. Never mind that you're the most educated generation in American history. The narrative was set.

You were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} on September 11, 2001—{{GRADE_AT_911}}. You watched the towers fall live, probably in a classroom or dorm common room. You saw people jump from windows. The teacher didn't know what to say. Nobody did. The before and after of that day split your life cleanly in two. Everything that came next—Afghanistan, Iraq, color-coded terror alerts, removing your shoes at airports—that was the world you'd become an adult in.

Your generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans, making you the largest living generation until Gen Z catches up. You were raised on participation trophies and told you could be anything, which was sweet until you graduated into the worst economy since the Great Depression and discovered that 'anything' didn't include a stable job with benefits.

The 2008 financial crisis hit when you were {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}. You'd been in the workforce just long enough to think you were building something. Entry-level jobs vanished. Unpaid internships became the only door, and even those were competitive. You watched your parents' retirement accounts collapse in real time. You learned, viscerally, that the system could fail—and that nobody would come to save you when it did.

You're wedged between Gen X (who bought houses when houses cost less than your student loans) and Gen Z (who never expected to buy houses at all). You still remember believing the system worked. You're not sure why you still believe it could be fixed.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Michael Jackson moonwalked for the first time the year you were born—Motown 25, May 1983. Thriller was still dominating every chart. That red leather jacket with too many zippers became the most imitated piece of clothing in America. By the time you were old enough to understand what you were watching, Jackson wasn't just a musician; he was a cultural weather system.

Return of the Jedi closed out the original Star Wars trilogy in 1983. Ewoks were controversial even then. By the time you saw it—probably on VHS, taped off TV with commercials you didn't bother skipping—the films were already sacred texts, cultural furniture. You didn't wait in line for a premiere. The movies simply existed, and so did your love for them.

The M*A*S*H finale aired in February 1983, drawing 105 million viewers—more than any single TV episode before or since. It was the end of an era, though you'd have to catch the reruns to understand why adults were crying over a show about a war that ended before your parents met.

Your childhood TV diet was pure sugar. Saved by the Bell taught you that high school would have a laugh track. Full House assured you every problem could be solved in twenty-two minutes with a hug. TGIF on ABC was appointment television—Family Matters, Step by Step, Boy Meets World. You learned about life from shows that bore no resemblance to actual life.

At ten, you were probably obsessed with The Lion King. 'Circle of Life' played at every school function. You cried when Mufasa died and you're still not over it. At twelve, you discovered Nirvana—or more likely, Nirvana discovered you through 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' playing on every radio station. Kurt Cobain died when you were ten, and suddenly the music felt different.

Your teenage years were TRL chaos. Backstreet Boys or *NSYNC—you had to choose a side, and the choice defined you. Britney vs. Christina. You learned all the moves to 'Bye Bye Bye' even if you'll deny it now. The Macarena at every school dance. 'MMMBop' stuck in your head for literally years. Your tastes were embarrassing, and everyone's tastes were embarrassing, and that was fine because everyone shared them.

Then came The Matrix in 1999, when you were fifteen, and suddenly everything needed bullet time and leather trench coats. You wanted to know kung fu. You wanted to take the red pill. You didn't fully understand the philosophy, but you understood that the world might not be what it seemed, and that felt true.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The first commercial mobile phone was released the year you were born—the Motorola DynaTAC 8000x, a $3,995 brick that weighed two pounds and lasted thirty minutes on a charge. Gordon Gekko types had them. The idea that you'd one day carry a phone in your pocket that was also a camera, computer, and entire music library would have seemed like fantasy.

Compact discs went mainstream in 1983. Your parents probably didn't get a CD player until the late '80s, which means your earliest music memories are cassettes—the satisfying click of the deck, the carefully curated mixtape, the agony of a chewed tape you tried to fix with a pencil. You experienced the CD revolution as a child, not understanding you'd eventually abandon physical media entirely.

At four, you might have encountered your first computer—an Apple IIe in a school computer lab, or a Commodore 64 at a friend's house. You played Oregon Trail and died of dysentery. You played Carmen Sandiego and learned geography. The machines felt magical and primitive at the same time.

You were twelve when Windows 95 launched with a $300 million marketing campaign. That startup sound became the anthem of the digital age. Suddenly, your family had a computer, and you learned to navigate it faster than your parents ever would. You played Minesweeper for hours. You got lost in the maze screensaver. The internet existed, technically, but you couldn't do much with it except wait.

At thirteen, you got your first email address—probably something embarrassing on Hotmail or AOL that you hope no one remembers. You learned to type by chatting on AIM, developing a fluency in instant messaging that would serve you well. The door-opening sound when your crush signed on. The away messages crafted like poetry. 'brb.' 'lol.' 'ttyl.' A language your parents didn't understand.

Napster launched when you were sixteen, and suddenly you had access to every song ever recorded—if you were willing to wait hours for a download on a 56k modem. You burned mix CDs with handwritten track lists. LimeWire after Napster died, viruses be damned. You learned to steal music before you were old enough to buy it legally.

Facebook opened to the public when you were twenty-three. You joined when it still required a .edu email and nobody's parents were on it. The iPhone launched when you were twenty-four, and everything before it suddenly looked ancient. You're the last generation that remembers life before the internet lived in your pocket. You can read a physical map. You can use a card catalog. These are superpowers now.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were three when the Challenger exploded. January 28, 1986. Schools across America had tuned in to watch Christa McAuliffe become the first teacher in space. Instead, seventy-three seconds after launch, seven people died on live television while millions of schoolchildren watched. You might not remember the explosion itself, but you remember the aftermath—the gravity in adult voices, the repeated footage, your first lesson that the world could break without warning.

You were six when the Berlin Wall fell. November 9, 1989. You were too young for geopolitics, but you understood something massive had happened. Crowds with sledgehammers, champagne, tears. Your parents remembered decades of nuclear anxiety. For you, the Cold War was just something that ended around the time you started first grade.

You were eight when the Soviet Union formally dissolved. The superpower that had defined global politics for forty-five years simply stopped existing. By the time you were paying attention to current events, there was only one superpower left, and you lived in it. The existential dread that shaped your parents' lives became a history lesson for you.

The Gulf War happened when you were seven. Yellow ribbons everywhere. CNN footage that looked like a video game—green night-vision, smart bombs finding their targets. Desert Storm was the first war designed for television, and you absorbed its sanitized imagery without understanding what war actually meant.

You were twelve when Oklahoma City happened. April 19, 1995. A truck bomb killed 168 people, including nineteen children in a daycare. Terrorism wasn't foreign anymore. It was domestic, and it looked like a guy who could have been your neighbor.

Columbine was April 20, 1999. You were fifteen—a sophomore, probably. Close enough in age that it felt like it could have been your school. The lockdown drills started after that. The clear backpacks. The constant question adults asked in lowered voices: 'Could it happen here?' You grew up learning to identify exits and hide under desks.

September 11, 2001 happened when you were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}}—senior year or freshman year of college. You already know where you were. That moment forged your generation's identity in a way nothing else could. The wars that followed—Afghanistan, Iraq—would define your entire adult life. Orange terror alerts became the new normal. Shoes off at airports, forever.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the financial system collapsed. At thirty-two, Trump won. At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, a pandemic shut down the world. You've lived through more 'unprecedented' events than most generations see in a lifetime. The word has lost all meaning.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You graduated college around {{COLLEGE_GRADUATION_YEAR}}, give or take. The dot-com bust had cleared. The economy seemed stable. You got a job, started building something, believed—briefly—that the rules your parents described still applied. Work hard, move up, get rewarded. The 2008 financial crisis disabused you of that fantasy with surgical precision.

You were twenty-five when Lehman Brothers collapsed. You'd been working just long enough to have something to lose. Entry-level positions suddenly required five years of experience. 'Just get your foot in the door' assumed doors existed. You watched colleagues get laid off and wondered when your turn would come. For some of you, it came quickly.

Your generation didn't invent the hustle—we perfected the grim art of needing one. You've probably held jobs that called themselves 'opportunities' instead of employment, which meant they came with exposure instead of healthcare. You learned that 'passion' was something employers wanted you to have so they could pay you less. 'Do what you love' meant 'accept poverty as a lifestyle choice.'

The gig economy wasn't built for your benefit—it was built to extract value from you while calling it freedom. 'Be your own boss' meant no benefits, no stability, no protection. Uber, TaskRabbit, Fiverr—platforms that turned every skill into a race to the bottom. You've been a 'contractor' at jobs that looked suspiciously like employment, minus the rights.

You remember when job loyalty was supposed to mean something. Your parents worked for companies that kept people for decades, offered pensions, provided actual security. By the time you started working, that contract had been shredded. You've never expected an employer to be loyal to you because none ever were. Job-hopping isn't disloyalty—it's rational self-defense in a market that treats workers as disposable.

Open office plans were supposed to foster collaboration. They fostered migraines and constant distraction. Unlimited PTO meant zero PTO because taking time off was career suicide. All-hands meetings about values happened while executives gave themselves bonuses and laid off your department. You learned to decode corporate speak: 'restructuring' meant layoffs, 'pivot' meant panic, 'family' meant they expected you to sacrifice like family without compensating you like one.

COVID proved you could work from anywhere. It also proved employers expected you to work everywhere, always, Slack pinging at midnight. The commute disappeared. The boundary between work and life disappeared with it.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember when getting someone's phone number felt like a victory, even though calling meant talking to their parents first? When seeing your crush at the mall was a full-body event? When passing a note in class—folded into that complicated triangle pattern—felt dangerously intimate?

You learned to flirt through AIM away messages. Song lyrics meant something. You went 'idle' when you weren't actually idle, waiting to see if they'd message first. The door-opening sound when they signed on. The agony of watching them go away without saying anything. The carefully crafted away messages designed to seem casual: 'out living life' when you were actually staring at the screen hoping they'd notice.

Your first relationships predated the internet's total intrusion into dating. You met people at parties, through friends, in classes, at jobs. Dating was still somewhat mysterious—you didn't have their entire social history available before the first date. You couldn't stalk their ex's Instagram because Instagram didn't exist. Privacy was the default, not a setting.

Tinder launched when you were thirty. By then, you'd already had serious relationships the old way. The app changed everything—courtship became a sorting algorithm. Swipe right, swipe left, reduce people to photos and a bio. You adapted, because that's what you do, but something was lost in the transition from serendipity to selection.

You've delayed marriage, not because you don't believe in partnership, but because the math doesn't work. Average wedding: $30,000. Average house: you can't afford one. Student loans: still paying them in your forties. The timeline your parents followed—married by 25, house by 28, kids by 30—isn't available at any price. You're not commitment-phobic. You're priced out of commitment's traditional markers.

Your friendships span time zones. You've moved for work, for school, for cheaper rent, for relationships that didn't work out. You maintain decades-old connections through group chats where nobody needs context explained because everyone lived it together. You know how to stay close to people who are far away. Distance taught you that friendship isn't proximity—it's showing up, even digitally.

You're the bridge generation in communication. You remember when long-distance calls cost money by the minute. You remember when email was novel. You adapted to texting, then social media, then video calls becoming normal. You're fluent in technologies your parents struggle with and nostalgic for technologies Gen Z has never seen.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three economic collapses before you turned forty. The dot-com bust when you were seventeen. The 2008 financial crisis when you were twenty-five. COVID when you were thirty-seven. Each one taught you the same lesson: the floor can fall out at any moment, and nobody's coming to catch you.

Your relationship with money isn't rational—it's trauma response. You save obsessively because you've seen how fast stability disappears. You're skeptical of the market because you've watched it crash twice during your working life, but you invest anyway because the alternatives are worse. You track your accounts more often than is healthy. Every dip in the market triggers the memory of 2008.

The ratio tells the story. A median home now costs six times the median income. Your parents bought houses for two years' salary. They got pensions—actual guaranteed retirement income. You got 401(k)s and the advice to 'just invest in index funds' while rent takes 40% of your paycheck.

You graduated with an average of $30,000 in student debt—for a degree you were told was mandatory for the middle class. The interest compounded while you made minimum payments because there was nothing left after rent, utilities, health insurance. You'll be paying this debt into your fifties. Maybe sixties.

The avocado toast discourse wasn't just insulting—it was gaslighting. The idea that your financial struggles come from $8 breakfast items rather than housing costs that tripled while wages stayed flat. The math is simple: your parents could buy a house on a middle-class salary. You cannot. Skipping brunch won't make a down payment appear.

You've redefined success by necessity. Homeownership isn't the goal—it's a fantasy for many of you. Retirement at 65 isn't the plan—it's a hope, maybe. You're not building generational wealth; you're trying not to become a burden on kids you might not be able to afford. Financial security means something different when the system extracts from you rather than builds with you.

And yet you keep playing, because the alternative is giving up entirely. You contribute to retirement accounts knowing the math might not work. You build emergency funds knowing emergencies will probably drain them. You budget and optimize and sacrifice, not because it guarantees anything, but because not trying feels worse than trying and failing.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

You're so good at adapting that you've forgotten adaptation isn't the goal. You've optimized your resume, your LinkedIn, your morning routine, your sleep schedule. You treat systemic problems as personal productivity challenges. The housing crisis isn't a policy failure—it's a budgeting problem you can spreadsheet your way out of. Except you can't. Some things aren't solvable by working harder or smarter.

Your coping mechanisms have become invisible to you. You call it self-care when it's survival. You call it hustle culture when it's exploitation you've accepted. You've normalized things that should be outrageous: healthcare tied to employment, education requiring debt, retirement as a fantasy. The water you swim in is toxic, and you've stopped noticing the taste.

Irony is your native language, and it's limiting you. You can't just like something—you have to like it ironically, or critique it while consuming it, or distance yourself with self-deprecating humor. Earnestness feels dangerous. Sincerity feels cringe. This makes it hard to fight for things you actually want. You can mock the system, but mocking isn't changing.

You're conflict-averse in ways that cost you. You've been trained to be team players, to bring solutions not problems, to not rock the boat. You'll accept 'that's just how it is' as an explanation. You'll endure toxic workplaces because the job market is brutal and you need health insurance. You've mistaken accommodation for maturity.

The digital world feels like action but is often performance. You can mobilize for causes on Twitter, share infographics, change profile pictures. But voter turnout in local elections—where policy actually changes—lags far behind engagement metrics. You can cancel celebrities, but changing zoning laws requires showing up to boring city council meetings. The dopamine hit of righteous posting isn't the same as power.

And maybe the deepest blind spot: you blame yourself. You've internalized the narrative so completely that you forget to question who wrote it. The self-improvement industry thrives because it's easier to sell you a solution than to fix the system. You've spent so long optimizing yourself that you've forgotten to ask why the optimization is necessary. The benchmarks keep moving. At some point, you have to stop chasing and start asking who set the course.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2003-2013): This was supposed to be the decade of possibility. You graduated college around 2005, entered a seemingly stable economy, and started building something. Then 2008 happened. Entry-level jobs evaporated. Unpaid internships became the only door. You watched friends who'd done everything right—good grades, good degrees, good attitudes—bartending and driving cabs. You took jobs you were overqualified for. You moved back home or crammed into apartments with too many roommates. The life script your parents followed wasn't available at any price. You delayed marriage, kids, homeownership—not by choice, but by math.

Your 30s (2013-2023): You made more money than you did at twenty-five, but it didn't feel like more. Rent went up. Groceries went up. The goalposts moved while you were running. You watched housing prices climb while your down payment fund stagnated. 'Settling down' felt like a trap, or a luxury, or both. Some of you got married, had kids, bought houses against the odds. Some of you decided those milestones weren't for you. Either way, COVID hit when you were thirty-seven, upending whatever normal you'd managed to construct. You pivoted, adapted, survived. Again.

Your 40s (2023-2033): You're here now, or approaching it. Statistically, this is your peak earning decade. You have authority at work, clarity about what you want, acceptance of what you can't change. If you have kids, they're getting older—needing less of your physical presence and more of your attention, your wisdom, your accumulated experience. Your parents are aging, needing more from you in ways you didn't anticipate. You're sandwiched between generations, managing everyone's needs. This is the decade where you either double down on the life you've built or blow it up and start over. Both choices are valid.

Your 50s (2033-2043): Pre-retirement age with no expectation of actually retiring. You'll have lived through at least four economic crises, probably two pandemics, and so many 'unprecedented' events that the word means nothing. You'll mentor younger people who can't imagine life before smartphones, and you'll catch yourself sounding like the older generations you once resented. You'll understand why they were the way they were—not cynicism, but experience.

Your 60s and beyond (2043+): Retirement, if it exists for you, won't look like your grandparents' version—the pension, the gold watch, decades of leisure. It'll be part-time work, maybe gig economy participation, reliance on systems that may or may not still exist. Climate change will have reshaped where people can live. The world will be unrecognizable. And you'll tell younger people about Saturday morning cartoons, about Blockbuster Friday nights, about dial-up modems and AIM away messages. They won't believe you. It'll sound like science fiction in reverse.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year as you. You're part of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials—the largest living generation, though Gen Z is catching up. You're elder Millennials, which means you remember things your younger generational siblings don't: a world before ubiquitous internet, before smartphones, before social media colonized every moment.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): They got the same degrees and entered a job market that actually hired people. They bought houses in their twenties—not because they were more responsible, but because houses cost less than three decades of income. They had pensions, or at least the tail end of them. They came of age during economic expansion; you came of age in an economic crater. The difference isn't work ethic or character. It's timing, and timing is luck dressed up as merit.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is almost comical. When Boomers were your age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. You control about 7%. A house in 1980 cost roughly two years of median income. They bought their forever homes at twenty-eight and watched them appreciate 400% while they slept. They're not wrong that they worked hard. They're wrong that working hard is sufficient.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You remember the before times—before the internet was everywhere, before phones were portals, before childhood was documented and uploaded. They don't. You still believe, somewhere deep down, that the system can be reformed. They've built around it, assuming it's broken. You adapted to technology; they were born into it. You have nostalgia; they have nihilism dressed up as irony. Neither of you has savings, but you feel bad about it and they've made peace with it.

Your life expectancy is 78-80 years—slightly lower than previous generations, thanks to rising 'deaths of despair' (suicide, overdose, alcoholism). Your generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before, which gets treated as a personal failing rather than a rational response to irrational conditions.

But you've also made the world genuinely better. You normalized therapy and destigmatized mental health struggles. You pushed for marriage equality, racial justice, trans rights—movements your parents' generation resisted or ignored. You inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. The economy is rigged against you, but culture shifted because you showed up. That matters, even when the rent is due.

year_events: Cabbage Patch Kids caused shopping riots
Return of the Jedi completed the Star Wars trilogy
The Day After aired, terrifying 100 million viewers
